title: What's News: World-Wide — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (September 16, 2019).

Iran denied American accusations that it was behind Saturday's strikes on Saudi oil facilities as Riyadh, and Washington rushed to respond to attacks that threatened to spark a broader clash with Iran.

The loss of nearly 6% of global oil output in the strikes sent crude prices soaring as Saudi officials said the kingdom was racing to restore roughly one-third of the disrupted production by day's end Monday.

North Korea's cyber operations have become a crucial revenue stream and a threat that could soon rival its weapons programs.

Federal judges bemoaned a partisan political environment that has led Trump and others to label them as extensions of the presidents who appointed them.

Some Senate Republicans are trying to team up with Democrats to reassert congressional authority over the levying of tariffs.

Documents prepared by U.S. prosecutors outline for the first time the possible role of the late Venezuelan leader Chávez in drug trafficking into the U.S.

Political turmoil engulfing Hong Kong showed no signs of abating as tens of thousands marched in defiance of a police ban.

Netanyahu is staking his political survival in Israel's election on his record protecting the country as he faces a challenge from former generals.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

September 16, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
